value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">3</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">depths of silence, writing that <del>was</del> <del>long</del> vast poem</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-faer" key="Faerie Queene, The">Faery Queen</rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The artist however had chosen his medium. The</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">great English art was not to be <del>l</del> music, or painting:</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it was to be the art of words. And if we call</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><add place="margin">we call</add> Spenser the first artist, it is because we <del>can</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>are aware of his</del> <del>of his</del> <add place="above">he was</add> awareness of his medium</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He was conscious not only of his public, not only</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of his own need, a poor man, of patronage &</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">support, but of the <del>limitations of the</del> fact that</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the language was truly an [incitement?]</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>It</del> "Let us be Kings of our language...</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>Let</del> In order <del>to be an artist, must one</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The writer, like the chronicler, in order to see his</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">medium cautiously, must be aware of the past</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>There</del> There must be a golden age behind him; &</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>y</del> the present must be fallen, degenerate.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But which <del>we</del> the modern writer, who has a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">long tradition behind him, <del>who</del> naturally</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">attacks the <del>old</del> generation which has just</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">past, thus giving himself a person to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">revolt against, the writer in Spenser's time,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">had no definite past. This is a more general</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">reaction. This <del>rather</del> a sense of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">[delicacy? debauchery?] the decay the language of its</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that he has to correct, rather than</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">his actual predecessors.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Thus Spenser, on the threshold of his</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">work as a poet, did not demolish his</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">predecessors; he complained of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">debasement of English speech: <del>& the</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He <del>used</del> the old <del>Chaucerian</del> language</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">recovered the old words, <del>the</del> <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-gcha" key="Chaucer, Geoffrey">Chaucers</rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">words. <del>He</del> Curious perhaps of his own</l>
